docs.lead_paragraph: WHILE surrounding office markets thrived last year, Westchester County's -- tied to large corporations -- ended with a higher vacancy rate than in 1997, leading some brokers to wonder what it would take to turn the market around. The county had a vacancy rate of 18 percent, up from 16.5 percent in 1997, according to Insignia/ESG, a commercial brokerage. And in the White Plains market, which is the county's business hub, the rate hovered at 30 percent, up from 28.3 percent a year earlier, making the city one of the worst-performing office markets in the country.

headline.main: Commercial Property / Westchester; Big Corporate Shifts Raise Office Vacancies to 18%

docs.abstract: Westchester County, NY, saw 1998 vacancy rate of 18 percent, up from 16.5 percent in 1997; in White Plains, county's business hub, rate hovered at 30 percent, up from year-earlier 28.3 percent; corporate reductions and move-outs cited; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: JAY GATSBY was a bond guy in F. Scott Fitzgerald's yarn of the Roaring Twenties. The bond market was also the playground for John Meriwether's 1990's band of Nobel laureate-speculators who made eight-figure fortunes for Long-Term Capital Management before its recent meteoric fall. Traditionally, though, bonds have been seen as boring, arcane investments suitable only for the aged, the already rich, the unimaginative and the hopelessly conservative. Not all that long ago, bond yields were lower than those on stocks on the grounds that it was stocks -- can you believe it? -- that people thought might carry some risk.

headline.main: Guide to Bonds: Risky, Arcane, But Essential

docs.abstract: Article explains arcane world of bonds, which can be risky but which also have place in almost every investment portfolio; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MEDICAL preparations for trips to exotic places must include a visit to a doctor or travel clinic for inoculations and advice. But even trips to more conventional places like a spa in California or your cousin's cabin in Colorado should involve gathering items for first aid or other health problems that might arise. For many, this counsel is redundant. Some of my best friends are hypochondriacs, and I do travel with them. I scoff when they climb aboard with Merck Manuals bulging in their pockets, carrying a first-aid kit that's the size of a carpenter's toolbox.
docs.abstract: Practical Traveler column on medical preparations for trips to exotic places; suggests useful medicines and first-aid items (S)
docs.snippet: MEDICAL preparations for trips to exotic places must include a visit to a doctor or travel clinic for inoculations and advice. But even trips to more conventional places like a spa in California or your cousin's cabin in Colorado should involve...

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly five years ago, Oregon began putting an idea to work that seemed both harsh and humane: In return for health insurance paid by the government, the poor would be required to join health maintenance organizations and have their care rationed. Most tonsillectomies, infertility treatment, hernia surgery and removal of bunions would be denied. The program would support preventive and hospice care and, starting this month, doctor-assisted suicide, but rule out heroic intervention to stretch a life for a week or two.

headline.main: Oregon Falters On a New Path To Health Care

docs.abstract: Problems mount for Oregon's five-year-old plan to extend health insurance for the poor in return for their participation in health maintenance organizations and the rationing of health care; state has been forced to abandon promise of universal care; doctors routinely find ways to get around rationing; conflicts with Federal Medicaid regulators impede efforts to deny more treatments; requirement that employees insure all their workers or contribute to a fund to cover them died early on; spending for plan has climbed to $2.1 billion in 1997-to-1999 state budget period from $1.7 billion in 1995-to-1997 period; higher cigarette taxes have not offset increase, requiring more money from state's general fund (M)
docs.snippet: Nearly five years ago, Oregon began putting an idea to work that seemed both harsh and humane: In return for health insurance paid by the government, the poor would be required to join health maintenance organizations and have their care rationed.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The scrapbook that documents Camelia Cruz's days as a teen-age cancer patient is yellowing now, its photographs and clippings fading with time. On this sunny Monday morning, Mrs. Cruz cracked it open, as she does every now and then, unleashing a flood of memories from what seems like a former life. There she is in a wheelchair, bald and frail, her face shielded by a surgical mask, a white hospital blanket draped over her knees. There she is, smiling, her head swathed in a blue scarf beneath a sparkling tiara, on the day she was crowned Miss Periwinkle at a camp for children with cancer. There's Sandy Cuellar, her best friend from the hospital; Camelia clutched her hand as she died, at 16. Her newspaper obituary is in Mrs. Cruz's album, along with a rose petal from the funeral.

headline.main: Childhood Cancer Patients Find Survival Has Price

docs.abstract: More and more children are surviving cancer, but survival comes at a heavy price; many survivors have health problems caused by their radiation and chemotherapy, including heart, lung and kidney dysfunction, memory loss, infertility and even second cancers; added to this are social difficulties, from awkwardness in dating to difficulty finding jobs and health insurance; Camila Cruz of Baytown, Tex, describes her triumph over osteosarcoma as a teen-ager and its lingering aftermath; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST week, while governments and the press abroad dwelled on the harsh sentences meted out to Chinese dissidents, exuberant middle-class couples crowded into the newly opened Ikea warehouse store here, snapping up stylish, modestly priced furniture and housewares. As the Chinese and American Governments sparred over human rights, moviegoers rushed to see the season's hit, ''Be There or Be Square,'' a romantic comedy filmed in Los Angeles that affectionately caricatures the United States and the Chinese who go there to seek their fortunes.
docs.abstract: Foreign concern with China's harsh treatment of dissidents bewilders ordinary Chinese busy pursuing exciting new economic options in their own lives, such as opening of new Ikea store in Beijing; photo; many Chinese assume society will eventually have to liberalize, and say biggest threat to their personal freedoms would be souring of Chinese-US relations that might strengthen conservative forces at home (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It had all the ingredients of a fairy-tale romance. They are from ethnic working-class families but attended an Ivy League school, entering Columbia University at the same time, in the fall of 1989. He becomes a two-time all-Ivy League wide receiver in football and makes the dean's list; she is an all-academic Ivy point guard in basketball. They meet, don't connect, then fall in love after they happen to take a course together as juniors, History of Ancient Mesopotamia. After graduating, he remains in New York to do research at a local hospital, she travels to Europe to play pro basketball for a season in Austria. They carry on a long-distance relationship, but when she returns to New York, he is off to the University of North Carolina to study for a Ph.D. in biochemistry.

headline.main: From Columbia, an Athletes' Romance, in Sickness and in Laughter

docs.abstract: Article on romance between Mike Sardo, two-time all-Ivy League wide receiver in football from Columbia University, and Kathleen Johnson, all-acaemic Ivy point guard in basketball; focuses on how the couple is coping with Sardo's cancer of the spine; couple plans to marry in July; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the Prudential Insurance Company of America decided last month to sell its health-care operations to Aetna Inc., it was the latest example of a company that could not make money caring for sick people. Despite Prudential's best efforts, the business, mostly in managed care, had lost hundreds of millions of dollars. Prudential finally gave up. The last few years have proved enormously difficult for many of the businesses created to capture the vast sums flowing through the nation's health-care system -- now more than $1 trillion each year. In particular, companies designed to oversee the delivery of care, like H.M.O.'s and groups of doctors' practices, are struggling.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; For Managed Care, Free-Market Shock

docs.abstract: Enormous difficulties of many companies that entered health care business discussed; majority of health maintenance organizations lost money in 1997, accumulating nearly $800 million in losses, which has led to cuts in services as rosy images of fat profits fade; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-13 In Dealing With Baghdad, U.S. Takes a Long View Nearly eight years after the 1991 Persian Gulf war started, Saddam Hussein is still shooting at American pilots and Washington still has no clear strategy for defeating him. And now, with the United Nations weapons inspectors gone from Iraq and unlikely to return, Mr. Hussein is free to build biological and chemical weapons without the world looking over his shoulder. Meanwhile, Iraq announced it would ban returning American and British inspectors. 10 American officials are casting their nets wide to find a credible opposition leader or perhaps a figurehead who might lead Iraq after Saddam Hussein, meeting even with a man who would be king. 10 Land of Uncertain Justice Despite the defeat of the Khmer Rouge and international efforts to establish the rule of law, the jailing of two rights workers shows that Cambodia remains a land of arbitrary justice, where neither mass killers nor ordinary citizens can be quite sure what to expect. 12 Tensions Rising in Korea North Korea seems to have grown more hard-line and militarized in recent months, and some experts fear a major security crisis on the Korean Peninsula later this year. 13 Nigeria Reinforces Delta Hundreds of Nigerian troops reinforced positions in the oil-producing Niger Delta, where as many as 19 youths have been reported killed in protests to demand a greater share of the region's oil wealth, residents said. 7 NATIONAL 14-20 Opposition May Lessen To Global Warming Treaty Even as a proposed treaty on global warming faces an uncertain future in the Senate, big companies are maneuvering to push through a bill to give them credit for any reductions in waste gases that they achieve before the treaty takes effect in 2008. The legislation would potentially moderate opposition to the treaty. 1 Oregon Health Plan's Woes Nearly five years ago, Oregon established a plan to give the poor health insurance but require them to join health maintenance organizations. With that, the state calculated, it could afford to provide basic care for all the poor. But now the state has abandoned that goal. 1 Cruise Industry Regulation A long inquiry by the Government discovered a fleet-wide conspiracy within Royal Caribbean Cruises to save millions of dollars by dumping oily waste into the ocean. A review of the criminal investigation and details of another dumping incident show the difficulty of policing the booming cruise industry. 1 Childhood Cancer Survivors Childhood cancer has been transformed from killer to curable disease. But thankful though they and their families are that they are alive, the growing legion of survivors are discovering that the miracle has not been without a price. 1 First 1999 Storm A giant storm howled across the Midwest from the Canadian border to the Gulf of Mexico, grounding most flights in Chicago and St. Louis, knocking out power, and threatening a foot of snow or more in Northern states. 14 NEW YORK/REGION 23-28 Sprinkler Mystery Remains In a Fatal Brooklyn Fire Investigators may never find out who turned off the sprinkler system in a Brooklyn high-rise building where three firefighters died in a fire last month. But an equally troubling mystery is how the system's uselessness could have gone undiscovered, probably for years. 23 Ghost Fleet Is Vanishing Hundreds of hulks of sailing ships, tugboats and other craft lie sunken in the mud of New York Harbor, but they are vanishing under the press of shoreline redevelopment. The United States Army Corps of Engineers has drawn up a list of 75 historically significant vessels to be studied and possibly salvaged before all the hulks are cleared out to prevent drifting timbers from threatening passing ships. 23 Stadium Seating at the Movies To hear moviegoers tell it, a universal gripe is becoming less common in the metropolitan region thanks to the latest in theater design: stadium-style seating that puts patrons head and shoulders above the row in front of them. 27 NEEDIEST CASES 24 OBITUARIES 29 Mary Ann Unger A sculptor and curator whose work is in the collections of the Hirschhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, the Brooklyn Museum of Art and the Philadelphia Museum of Art, she was 53. 29 David Manners The Hollywood actor of the 1930's who played the hero in Tod Browning's 1931 ''Dracula,'' he was 98. 29 Jean-Claude Forest The creator of the science fiction comic strip character Barbarella and set designer for the 1968 movie starring Jane Fonda, he was 68. 29 Eric Crull Baade A scholar of the classics, teacher and co-author of a widely used Latin textbook series, he was 70. 29 Chess 28 Weather 28 TV Update 27

docs.lead_paragraph: As Tim Gimbel sees it from the double-wide trailer near here where he now spends his days, even working a drilling rig when it's 25 below beats a layoff. He will not have the money to build a garage this summer, so his wife, Laura, has at least two more winters of creeping an icy hundred yards uphill every morning to fetch her car from a shed as she leaves for her job as a secretary. She often asks how soon her husband expects to be called back, or why he wants to remain a driller in the first place, and whether there aren't more dependable ways to make a living. ''She's done everything but put her boots on and kick me out the door,'' Mr. Gimbel said.

headline.main: For Oilfield Workers, Not the Best of Times
